title: Musing about a Russian Vyaz font
content:
I was toying around with an idea of a new Vyaz' font for a while now, but the sheer mind-boggling amount of ligatures and heavy scripting required to accommodate a proper and versatile face seemed unmanageable. Thus, I finally decided that a simple vector file would be a better alternative, with a basic modular design, a handful of letter alternatives, ligatures and decorative elements, providing the user with the freedom to construct their own combinations. here are the first sketches of this Idea:

Church Slavonic:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707im_/http:/typophile.com/files/vyaz5_4913.gif)

Longer passage without archaic letters:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707im_/http:/typophile.com/files/vyaz4_5848.gif)

Different ligature options:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707im_/http:/typophile.com/files/liga_5815.png)

This is what I am trying to base it on:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707im_/http:/typophile.com/files/historicvyaz_6075.gif)
author: oprion

_would a Latin version be of use to anyone, or just help propagate corny Russian-esque kitch._

Why not "try it and see". Anyone can have a clever idea (or kill it at the concept stage), but until you actually try and work out an idea you never know how it will turn out in reality, or what paths it will lead down. It's also my experience, having created a few oddball faces, that there's always someone somewhere who will find a use for whatever you throw down (and it will most likely be something you never anticipated); fonts are the perfect "Long Tail" product.

No, I can't, but it seems it should keep the snow from drifting onto the roads.

Cheers!

\> _Why not adapt the idea to the Latin Script?_

It reminds me of a [set of books](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/www.atelierreneknip.nl/assets/images/08print-bnobooks.jpg) René Knip designed for the BNO in 2002/2001.

That Vyaz style is absolutely mesmerizing!

The [Barcode](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Barcode) idea has been done before with the Latin script. But that's no reason something more decorative along the Vyaz lines couldn't also be worked out.

David -- You'd have to set it far enough back from the road to allow for the long tail, depending upon how strong the average winds are.

-- K.

Victor, _[vyaz’](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/typophile.com/node/14390)_ (_вязь_) is an [ancient Cyrillic calligraphy style](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/www.paratype.com/help/term/terms.asp?code=369). There was [an earlier discussion](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/typophile.com/node/14377) of _vyaz’_ on typophile.com, in view of the advanced typographic features of the OpenType technology (contextual glyph substitution on the fly).

As to [_Gzhel’_](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gzhel) and [_Khokhlomà_](http://web.archive.org/web/20150401064707/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khokhloma), those are traditional folk techniques of pottery-making and decorating, and painting wooden tableware, named after the villages they originated in.
